review.title: Fuzzy Mixed Integer Linear Programming for Air Vehicles Operations Optimization
review.abstract: Multiple Air Vehicles (AVs) to prosecute geographically dispersed targets is an important optimization problem. Associated multiple tasks viz., target classification, attack and verification are successively performed on each target. The optimal minimum time performance of these tasks requires cooperation among vehicles such that critical time constraints are satisfied i.e. target must be classified before it can be attacked and AV is sent to target area to verify its destruction after target has been attacked. Here, optimal task scheduling problem from Indian Air Force is formulated as Fuzzy Mixed Integer Linear Programming (FMILP) problem. The solution assigns all tasks to vehicles and performs scheduling in an optimal manner including scheduled staged departure times. Coupled tasks involving time and task order constraints are addressed. When AVs have sufficient endurance, existence of optimal solution is guaranteed. The solution developed can serve as an effective heuristic for different categories of AV optimization problems.

Here, the problem of optimal task scheduling by the Indian Air Force is formulated as a Fuzzy Mixed Integer Linear Programming (FMILP) problem, which assigns all tasks to the vehicles and performs the planning in an optimal way, including scheduled departure times.Coupled tasks with time and task series limitations are tackled. If AVs have sufficient endurance, the presence of an optimal solution is guaranteed, and the solution developed can serve as effective heuristics for various categories of AV optimization problems.Keywords: Fuzzy Mixed Integer Linear Programming, Air Vehicles, Planning, Scheduling

sections.heading: 5 Discussion on Problem size
sections.text: Taking into account the AV optimization problem in section 3 and the corresponding illustrative example in section 4, here is a discussion of the problem size. For n targets, vehicles, and m = 3 tasks per target, the problem size is n (n - 1) wm + nwm + 2nw + 2nw + 1 decision variables, of which 3 + nm + 1 are continuous time variables and rest binary decision variables. The number of constraints is also growing rapidly. There are 12 (n - 1) nw + 9nw + 2nwm + 2nm + 3w constraints, of which mn + w are equality constraints and 7nw + 2w are non-time constraints, and 12 (n - 1) nw + 2nw + 2nwm + inequality time constraints are temporal constraints. The size of the FMILP increases rapidly as the problem size increases. Some practical problems can be led to an optimal solution with this formulation, with variable decisions 2 = 51.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, the FMILP model is presented to find an optimal solution for NP Complete, a complex problem where tasks are coupled by time and time constraints. Taking into account the linearity and associated uncertainty in real data, the problem of AV optimization is formulated as FMILP by treating the time variable as continuous; the mathematical formulation allows staggered AV departure times to ensure that the time constraints are met and different task fulfillment times are incorporated into the optimization model, where feasibility is ensured provided that the number of UAVs deployed exceeds the number of targets and the UAV endurance is sufficiently high; the formulation is flexible enough to allow various alternative performance functions; the strict formulation allows a true optimal solution to demanding assignment and scheduling problems; experimental results are presented for real-world problems of the Indian Air Force, which the efficiency of the FILP solution can serve as an effective solution to today's problem categories.
